text:
(1)
350 to 342 West Houston Street, western section (formerly Hammersley Street), at and adjoining the north corner of West Street.
May 12, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
342 to 350 West Houston Street, the same scene viewed from the east, two years later. Everything in this westernmost block of West Houston Street will be demolished in 1930, and the street later closed.
March 8, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
350 to 342 West Houston Street, western section (formerly Hammersley Street), at and adjoining the north corner of West Street.
May 12, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
342 to 350 West Houston Street, the same scene viewed from the east, two years later. Everything in this westernmost block of West Houston Street will be demolished in 1930, and the street later closed.
March 8, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), east from and including West Street. Hammersley Street was one of the group of parallel east-west streets laid out in the Trinity Church Farm, and met the western end of the original Houston Street just east across the line between the Trinity Farm and the West Bayard Farm, at the southern end of Bedford Street (q.v.).

In 1858 this street lost its own name and was absorbed by Houston Street. At that time, and thereafter till the redistricting of 1917, it served as the southern boundary of the Ninth Ward, which was roughly identical with Greenwich Village.

In 1930 these buildings at and east of West Street will be demolished for the site of the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal (see West Street). Houston Street, from West to Washington Streets, will be permanently closed and incorporated with the site of the freight station.

March 6, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street), south side, from West Street towards Greenwich Street. The Church of the Holy Comforter used to stand at No. 345-341, where the billboards now hide the vacant lot; it was taken down less than eight years before the date of this picture.
June 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a view all the way to Greenwich Street, three months later after the West to Washington Street block has been cleared, showing the east side of Washington Street, and, in the background, the new Standard Statistics Building under construction on the west side of Hudson Street, from King to Charlton Streets.
September 30, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.
